narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Developed skills in institutional analysis and application of Institutional Analysis and Development Framework; gained insight into institutional economic theory and features of American democracy.
First and foremost, students learn how to interact with and use the IAD framework. Being that the class is a WR credit, it is also really practice in good essay writing.
This class emphasized institutional analysis in general more than any particular issue of democracy or sustainability.
I learned a lot about the role of science in policy-making, the IAD framework, and lobsters!

Professor Fotos' course allowed students to grapple with issues regarding sustainability around the world through an in-depth application of the IAD framework.  Students were able to greatly improve their writing through weekly assignments - to which Professor Fotos provided detailed individual feedback.
I gained such a greater depth in my understanding of government, democracy, and the principles of leadership in this class.
Greatly improved my ability to think on the spot, as well as my ability to frame policy issues within an economic framework (IAD Framework).

The class is revolved around the study of Social Ecological System and Institutional Analysis Development, which are frameworks used to analyze a specific community/ecosystem or a specific policy in such contexts. I also learn about democratic practices and how to speak about community resilience and robustness, which is great considering that we are in the middle of one of the most sociopolitically transitional periods of US modern history.

This course focused on the institutions that arise from individual self-governance, and showed that such institutions are generally more sustainable than rules generated by vertical or top-down representation. I developed a greater understanding of the importance of democracy in ensuring a sustainable and equitable future. I also learned a lot about theory in political science, and how democracy in theory and democracy in practice often differ.
Institutional analysis as it relates to democracy and sustainability challenges.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - class participation, instructor support, regular feedback, and assignment relevance. 

Weaknesses -

There are many strengths, most important to me that Professor Fotos fostered a lovely culture in the class, even though it was virtual. I became friends with all of my classmates. Additionally, Professor Fotos brought in a bunch of really interesting guest lecturers. Another strength is that students are encouraged to take leadership roles within class. I can't think of any structural weaknesses.

On strengths, this class granted a tremendous amount of freedom in pursuing our interests. The semester-long research allowed us to really delve into a topic we are passionate about. On weaknesses, there was a lot of reading each week, so much that we usually didn't even reference 90% of it.
This course is amazing as is.

The course was excellent. I would say that its foremost strength was Professor Fotos' incredible perspectives on the course material and his dedication to his students. The course's syllabus was extremely well organized and had fascinating readings. These were also supplemented by Professor Fotos' weekly written memos to students that enabled us to engage even more closely with the texts we read. The course was also highly engaging. Professor Fotos' teaching style fostered in-depth discussions of the course's major topics that enabled students to learn from each other as well as from the professor. This was complemented by many group writing activities in class and fascinating guest lecturers.

I looked forward to this class every week.  The discussions were always productive and very interesting.  The culture was probative and intellectual without ever being combative.  
At times, there was more reading than I could keep up with but that may have just been my fault.

Weekly readings were very heavy, and at times very dense (especially in the beginning, when learning the theory behind the framework). Class discussions were very compelling, and almost everyone had a chance to speak every week. The prompts for the assignments were vague, leading to a lot of potential interpretation for submissions, but Professor Fotos did not seem to mind the variation.

Strength: The class is very well-structured, perhaps one of the best at Yale. Professor Fotos is really thorough about what he expects in every class, owing in no small way to the fact that he actively takes care of and revises the class syllabus every year. Weaknesses: the SES and IAD frameworks are interesting to know, but hard to effectively apply right away. It is so generalizable that there is so much opacity in some of the terminologies, yet it is expected that we are really meticulous about technical jargon. The papers become a bit hard to write for that reason.

The in-class discussions were quite engaging despite the Zoom format. Professor Fotos did an excellent job of moderating the conservation and ensuring that all class members participated in the course. The readings were also interesting, though required a great deal of time to understand to a sufficient degree. I particularly enjoyed the more tangential readings - ones that were only indirectly related to class discussions of self-governance - such as Martin Luther King Jr.'s "Letter from Birmingham Jail." It was interesting to connect the self-governance lessons from class to historical essays on democracy.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Successes - use of Zoom's breakout-rooms feature, Canvas' conversation feature, and quick responses to emails. 

Need improvement - files for readings were at times hard to access and/or read.
I think Professor Fotos made the class enjoyable with his energy, and that helped me learn virtually. I can't think of anything that needs big improvements.
I liked how there was a plan for every seminar, so everything felt very organized. The breakout rooms were fun, especially since I got to meet and talk to people in the seminar.
I thought the level of engagement and discussion and use of breakout rooms was perfect.
Professor Fotos chose not to have a TA and let us rotate around acting like a TA for a specific class, which I found to be really engaging.

I thought this course transitioned quite well to the Zoom format. The class discussions were engaging and required participation from all course members. The work in breakout rooms was also entertaining. It was helpful to talk over the material in smaller groups, and the breakout rooms allowed me to get to know most of my classmates throughout the semester.
The use of breakout rooms could be improved--they get repetitive after a while.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Would highly recommend for both Environmental Studies and Political Science majors.

If you care about sustainability, this is a great class. There is no need to understand the politics behind sustainability because Professor Fotos allows you to take the material in whatever direction you want. I highly recommend this class.

I would definitely recommend it, but the title isn't quite what you'd expect. At first, I thought the title was misleading, but I don't think that's the case; the course definitely does focus on democracy and sustainability. However, this is a different approach than I expected.

Absolutely! Professor Fotos is a gem and he really cares for his students. You can tell he's passionate about what he teaches and that makes the course so much better. You get to do your paper on whatever interests you as well.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The course is extremely well organized and engaging. Professor Fotos presents the subject matter and the theory of the course's readings in a way that it can be understood even by students who are engaging with texts like Elinor Ostrom's "Governing the Commons" for the first time.
I have and will continue to recommend this class to everyone I know.  Professor Fotos is a wonderful professor and pedagogical treat.
Yes - it's a great course.

Yes, and do not expect it to have a low workload. It is a great Writing credit for anyone interested in the practice of democracy--the class is very practically minded, which is a bit funny considering there is a lot of theory to pick up.

I would recommend this course to another student. As my first political science course, it was incredibly informative, and gave me a new framework to analyze problems of self-governance and sustainability. The course material was wide-ranging and ambitious, so there is something in this course for everyone.
Yes absolutely  the interdisciplinary nature of the course materials illustrate how the subject material is connected and the discussions were always engaging.
